title: How to Make a Sticky Note Origami Flower

steps.title: Fold a square piece of paper in half diagonally.
steps.content: Fold a square piece of paper in half diagonally. It should now look like a triangle. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Fold the triangle’s bottom two corners of up to its point.
steps.content: Fold the triangle’s bottom two corners of up to its point. You should now have formed a square. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Fold each previous fold backwards halfway.
steps.content: Fold each previous fold backwards halfway . The back-folded back edges should line up with the edges of the “square” underneath. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Expand the triangles you folded in the previous step.
steps.content: Expand the triangles you folded in the previous step. Lift one side triangle, insert a finger to open the pocket inside, and re-flatten it along the crease so that it is expanded into a diamond. Repeat on the other side. If you're feeling confused, take a look at the image for further guidance. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Tuck in the triangular point sticking out on the left side.
steps.content: Tuck in the triangular point sticking out on the left side. If you open the left area of the folded paper slightly, you’ll see that, underneath the top sheet of paper, there’s a fold that half-covers the diamond underneath. Simply fold the point of the diamond into the body of the shape below the piece of paper that is half-covering it. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat with the triangular point on the right side.
steps.content: Repeat with the triangular point on the right side.

steps.title: Fold the left- and rightmost corners inward along the creases that already exist.
steps.content: Fold the left- and rightmost corners inward along the creases that already exist. The resulting outline should once again be a square. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Glue the top of the folded flaps where indicated by the image.
steps.content: Glue the top of the folded flaps where indicated by the image. Using a glue stick may be a good idea because it dries so quickly, but you can also use white liquid glue as shown here. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Bring the folded flaps together, fastening them in place.
steps.content: Bring the folded flaps together, fastening them in place. Squeeze the flaps together so that the glue takes, then pinch the creases together tightly so that the folds protruding into the cone stay somewhat centered. To hold the glued pieces together, secure them with a paperclip. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Make four more of these.
steps.content: Make four more of these. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Apply glue to the central seam of each piece.
steps.content: Apply glue to the central seam of each piece. This seam is where the folded edges meet (where they were glued together previously). Spread out the glue so that the centers of the pieces can stick together securely.

steps.title: Begin pressing the pieces together.
steps.content: Begin pressing the pieces together. The five cones will make the Kusudama flower’s five petals.

steps.title: Continue adding pieces until you’ve assembled the entire flower.
steps.content: Continue adding pieces until you’ve assembled the entire flower. Glue everything together in a circular formation. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Use paperclips to hold the petals together.
steps.content: Use paperclips to hold the petals together.

steps.title: Wait for the glue to dry completely before removing the paperclips.
steps.content: Wait for the glue to dry completely before removing the paperclips. Otherwise, the petals risk slipping apart.
